arm_group.description: In intervention period patients were received head-down 30 degree postural drainage position for 10 min.
In intervention period patients were received horizontal supine lying for 10 min.

brief_summary.textblock:
The purpose of this study is to explore acute hemodynamic and ventilatory responses to
      head-down 30 degree postural drainage position in patients with blunt chest and/or abdominal
      injury in the traumatic intensive care unit.

clinical_study.brief_title: Hemodynamic and Ventilatory Responses to Head-down Postural Drainage Position
clinical_study.condition: Traumatic Blunt Chest and/or Blunt Abdominal Injury

detailed_description.textblock:
Study Protocol The study protocol consisted of 2 conditions: treatment condition (A) and
      sham condition (B). The order of the conditions was randomly assigned to either the
      treatment or sham for the first round and vise versa in the second round in a balanced
      cross-over design (A-B-B-A) so there were four sets of measurements per patient.

      For the treatment condition (A), the study consists of three consecutive periods 1) baseline
      period: 10 minutes rest in horizontal supine lying 2) intervention period: 10 minutes rest
      in head-down 30 degree supine lying 3) recovery period: return to horizontal supine lying
      and rest for 10 minutes . For the Sham condition (B), the study was performed with a similar
      procedure except the intervention period consisted of horizontal supine lying.

      Hemodynamic and ventilatory parameter were recorded at the start of each period (0 min) and
      every 2 minute until end of each period for both conditions. Hemodynamic and ventilatory
      dependent variables were heart rate (HR), systolic blood pressure (SBP), diastolic blood
      pressure (DBP), mean arterial pressure (MAP), electrocardiography (ECG), central venous
      pressure (CVP), respiratory rate (RR), oxygen saturation (SpO2), tidal volume (VT), minute
      ventilation (VE), dynamic lung compliance (Cdyn) and end-tidal expiratory pressure of CO2
      (PETCO2). Subjects were rested between each condition. Subjects were suctioned via
      endotracheal tube to clear airway at 10 minutes before study commencement of either A-B or
      B-A.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  Mechanical ventilator dependence

          -  Stable cardiopulmonary function at rest (HR 60-100 beats/min, systolic BP 90-140 mmHg
             and diastolic BP 60-90 mmHg and SpO2>95%. RR 10-20 breath/min

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  Spine disorders such as spine fracture, HNP, spondylolisthesis, whiplash syndrome,
             stenosis and spondylosis

          -  Fracture of upper and/or lower limbs

          -  Underlying acute or chronic cardiopulmonary diseases

          -  Craniotomy or craniectomy

          -  Unstable intracranial pressure, ICP>12 cmH2O

          -  Uncontrolled pain

intervention.description: supine head down 30 degree on tilt table (intervention period in the treatment condition)
intervention.intervention_name: Head down 30 degree postural drainage position

intervention.description: horizontal supine lying on tilt table (intervention period in the sham condition)

clinical_study.official_title: Acute Hemodynamic and Ventilatory Responses to Head-down 30° Postural Drainage Position in Critically Traumatic Patients

overall_official.affiliation: Department of Physical Therapy, Khon Kaen Hospital

primary_outcome.description: Heart rate (HR) was recorded 3 times every 2 minute in each phase, each phase will have 10 minutes and each condition will have 3 phases (baseline, intervention, and recovery).
primary_outcome.measure: Change of heart rate (HR) from baseline.
primary_outcome.time_frame: measured every 2 minutes during each phase

primary_outcome.description: Systolic blood pressure (SBP) was recorded 3 times every 2 minute in each phase, each phase will have 10 minutes and each condition will have 3 phases (baseline, intervention, and recovery).
primary_outcome.measure: Change of systolic blood pressure (SBP) from baseline.
primary_outcome.time_frame: measured every 2 minutes during each phase

primary_outcome.description: Diastolic blood pressure (DBP) was recorded 3 times every 2 minute in each phase, each phase will have 10 minutes and each condition will have 3 phases (baseline, intervention, and recovery).

primary_outcome.time_frame: measures every 2 minutes in each phase
